column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Ecosystem|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Focalpoint|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Locationofstudy|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Mainhypothesisandcorrespondingresults|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Method|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Reccomendationsandsuggestions|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Researchquestions|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Timeperiodofstudy|
#Text=Effects of abiotic restoration through rock addition on invertebrate functional diversity in native temperate grasslands.

#Text=Isobel Roberts,�Richard N C Milner,�Brett Howland,�James Lumbers,�Maree Gilbert,�Annabel L Smith\rFirst published: 22 May 2024\r�\rhttps://doi.org/10.1111/rec.14192\rAuthor contributions: RNCM, BH, MG, ALS designed the study; RNCM, JL, IR, ALS collected the data; IR, ALS, RNCM designed the analytical approach; IR, ALS analyzed the data; IR wrote the paper in collaboration with ALS with input from RNCM, BH, JL, MG\rCoordinating Editor: Nicholas Barber.
#Text=Abstract.
#Text=Invertebrates account for over 90% of all described species and provide crucial ecosystem services.
#Text=Land clearing, including the removal of abiotic habitat features, threatens invertebrate biodiversity, making environmental restoration crucial for conservation.
#Text=However, little is known about the effects of abiotic restoration compared to the restoration of biotic features.

#Text=To determine if rock addition increased invertebrate biodiversity, we introduced 120t of rocks to 10 sites across five grassland reserves in the Australian Capital Territory in a before_after_control_impact design.
#Text=We sampled invertebrates using pitfall traps before treatment in 2016 and after rock addition in 2019 (during record_breaking drought).
#Text=We recorded 29,164 individual invertebrates from 19 orders and undertook a functional trait_based analysis of rock effects on the invertebrate community.
#Text=No effects of rock addition were observed on the probability of occurrence, richness, diversity, community similarity, or abundance of any taxonomic or functional group.
#Text=The abundance of snare_building spiders and large ants was higher in the control plots at the end of the experiment.
#Text=These abundance responses in 2019 did not differ from the control or treatment plots in 2016.
#Text=Thus, some combination of drought and rock addition appears to have neutralized a positive temporal change that was evident without rocks.
#Text=Despite a regionwide, replicated restoration effort and an extensive functional analysis of invertebrate communities, very little positive response to rock addition was recorded.

#Text=Rock addition did not have a negative effect on grassland invertebrate biodiversity and may still be beneficial to the long_term conservation and restoration of vertebrate and invertebrate communities.

#Text=Implications for Practice\r* Abiotic restoration in the form of adding rocks to grasslands did not have a positive or negative effect in the short term (3years) on invertebrate biodiversity.\r* Absence of rocks from plots provided a competitive advantage to some functional groups, namely big ants and snare_building spiders.\r* Rock addition has other positive effects on grasslands and may have a long_term positive effect on invertebrate biodiversity.\r* The effects of an extreme drought on invertebrates were not exacerbated by rock addition.
#Text=There is little risk of negatively impacting invertebrates with rocks, while there might be positive benefits in wetter years.
#Text=Introduction.

#Text=Invertebrates account for over 90% of all described species globally (Stork�2018; Karam_Gemael et al�2020) but are threatened by habitat loss and fragmentation, invasive species, and climate change (Hafernik�1992; Oliver et al�2016; Sands�2018).

#Text=Invertebrates provide crucial ecosystem services, including pollination, seed dispersal, and nutrient cycling, as well as providing food for higher trophic levels (Hafernik�1992; Kim�1993; Borges et al�2021).
#Text=As such, invertebrate abundance and biodiversity are frequently used as markers for ecosystem health and stability (Hoffmann & Andersen�2003; Andersen et al�2004; Borges et al�2021).

#Text=For example, the strong response of ants to habitat disturbance and environmental stress (Linksvayer & Janssen�2009) makes them useful markers of restoration success after land use change (Andersen et al�2004; Oberprieler & Andersen�2020).
#Text=It is crucial, therefore, that restoration projects encompass invertebrate communities to conserve biodiversity and retain ecosystem services.

#Text=Native grasslands cover roughly 9millionkm2�across all continents (excluding Antarctica) and host high levels of invertebrate diversity and endemicity (Carbutt et al�2017; Stork�2018; T�r�k et al�2021).

#Text=Native grasslands are also one of the most threatened ecosystem types, as their topography and productivity make them ideal for urbanization and agriculture (Keith�2004; Williams & Morgan�2015).
#Text=This has resulted in drastic loss and fragmentation of grasslands by up to 50% globally, and as much as 90% in some regions (Carbutt et al�2017; Bardgett et al�2021; Scholtz & Twidwell�2022).

#Text=Grasslands are still declining due to limited restoration funding, under_appreciation of their conservation significance (New�2019), agricultural intensification, forestry, urbanization, mining, and invasive species (Gang et al�2014; Veldman et al�2015; Carbutt & Kirkman�2022).
#Text=Restoration of native grasslands is therefore inordinately important given their global coverage, high biodiversity, and extensive loss and degradation.

#Text=Functional trait analysis of invertebrate communities has advanced scientific understanding of the ecological role invertebrates play while providing critical tools to monitor responses to climate change and land management (Andersen et al�2004; Borges et al�2021).
#Text=Ants, for example, frequently respond to changes in temperature, rainfall, and ground cover, making them useful indicators of environmental change (Hoffmann & Andersen�2003; Oliver et al�2016).
#Text=Invertebrate functional diversity can also indicate the effectiveness of restoration projects.

#Text=Some studies have shown functional trait diversification in response to the supplementation of key biotic resources such as herbaceous ground cover and leaf litter (Braschi et al�2021; Contos et al�2023).
#Text=Other studies have documented a lack of overall diversification of invertebrates in response to habitat restoration (Audino et al�2014; Sawski & Sawska�2019).

#Text=However, the bulk of research on invertebrate functional ecology has focused on the passive effects of land use change and management, with comparatively less research examining how functional traits respond to active restoration (Oberprieler & Andersen�2020; Braschi et al�2021).
#Text=Research examining changes in functional diversity following restoration is crucial in determining the effectiveness of conservation strategies.

#Text=Globally, most restoration efforts have focused on biotic supplementation such as revegetation (Carbutt & Kirkman�2022) and natural regeneration of plant communities (T�r�k et al�2021) to increase biodiversity and diversify microhabitats within ecosystems (Borges et al�2021; Carbutt & Kirkman�2022; Scholtz & Twidwell�2022).

#Text=Emerging evidence suggests that abiotic restoration, such as the addition of rocks (Croak et al�2010; Buisson et al�2015) or coarse woody debris (Barton et al�2011; Evans et al�2019), might play a crucial role in the recovery of ecosystem function where abiotic features have been lost due to anthropogenic processes (Michael et al�2021).
#Text=Habitat supplementation with rocks, eg has positively influenced reptile colonization in restored ecosystems (McDougall et al�2016; Alvarez & Guida_Johnson�2019; O'Sullivan et al�2023).

#Text=There is some evidence that rock addition diversifies microhabitats, increasing the diversity of invertebrates with specific thermal and behavioral requirements (Goldsbrough et al�2003; Robinson�2008; Mccaffrey & Galen�2011).
#Text=However, we are unaware of any study that has examined invertebrate functional trait response to rock addition.

#Text=Several invertebrate studies have indicated that functional traits can be used to measure habitat restoration success (Gerlach et al�2013; Borges et al�2021) and may be suitable for measuring the effectiveness of rock addition.

#Text=For example, one study found that foliage_dwelling spiders, which use webs to capture prey, responded positively to invasive plant control, while ground_dwelling spiders did not (Braschi et al�2021).

#Text=However, knowledge about the effects of abiotic restoration on invertebrate biodiversity is not sufficiently advanced to predict the outcome of restoration and conservation decisions with accuracy.
#Text=We aimed to determine whether rock supplementation increased invertebrate biodiversity and ecological function within a native temperate grassland in southeastern Australia.
#Text=Given the potential importance of rocks for invertebrate habitat, we hypothesized that the addition of rocks would positively affect invertebrate abundance and diversity.
#Text=We also expected rock addition would result in changes to community composition, which reflected distinct changes in functional groups.

#Text=Our study encompassed a broad diversity of invertebrate orders, including spiders (Araneae), cockroaches (Blattodea), beetles (Coleoptera), ants (Formicidae), crickets, and grasshoppers (Orthoptera).
#Text=We expected that the abundance of invertebrates with functional traits associated with dispersal, foraging, trophic level, and size would respond to rock addition within restored grasslands.
#Text=Such knowledge will assist in making restoration decisions that maintain or increase invertebrate biodiversity across degraded landscapes.
#Text=Methods.
#Text=Study Region and Design.

#Text=This study was undertaken across five nature reserves around the city of Canberra in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT): Crace Nature Reserve (lat 35.229S, long 149.133E), Kama Nature Reserve (lat 35 274S, long 149 023E), East Jerrabomberra Grassland Nature Reserve (lat 35 374S, long 149 180E), West Jerrabomberra Grassland Nature Reserve (lat 35.366S, long 149.159E), and Mulanggari Nature Reserve (lat 35 193S, long 149 138E) (Fig�1A).
#Text=This region has a cool temperate climate, with mean temperatures ranging between 13 and 28 degrees C in summer and 0 and 11 degrees C in winter.
#Text=The mean annual rainfall for the region is 629mm, with the yearly rainfall being highly variable (Australian Government Bureau of Meteorology).
#Text=Our study took place between 2016 and 2019, a period of extreme rainfall variability.
#Text=Rainfall in the first year of the study, 2016, was 908.4mm, which was the highest on record at the time.

#Text=Subsequent years had below_average rainfall leading to drought: 486.0mm in 2017, 472.0mm in 2018, and 372.8mm in 2019, the latter being the lowest recorded for Canberra at the time (Australian Government Bureau of Meteorology).
#Text=Figure 1\rMap of study locations, plot design, and expected responses.
#Text=(A) Invertebrate biodiversity was surveyed in five natural temperate grassland reserves around the city of Canberra, Australian Capital Territory (ACT).
#Text=Control and treatment plots are shown on the map in black and gray circles, respectively.
#Text=(B) At each reserve, two plot pairs in two replicate sites consisting of one control plot and one treatment plot spaced at least 100m apart.
#Text=The inset shows a close_up example of the study design, which was replicated all reserves.
#Text=(C) Within each plot, two parallel 15m drift fences were installed, each with two pitfall traps for collecting terrestrial invertebrates.
#Text=(D) We expected invertebrate biodiversity to increase on rock treatment plots, with no concurrent change on control plots.

#Text=Nature reserves in the ACT are dominated by natural temperate grassland, which is listed as threatened regionally (ACT Government�Nature Conservation Act�2014) and critically endangered nationally (Australian Government�Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act�1999).
#Text=Only small fragments (25__140ha) of these grasslands remain within a matrix of urban and agricultural land that was primarily used for sheep grazing and, more recently, cattle grazing (Fig�1).
#Text=As part of these practices, extensive areas of rock are believed to have been either removed or displaced.

#Text=Since being gazetted as Nature Reserves (between 1995 and 2007), reserves have been managed for conservation purposes, including weed control, ecological burning, and modifying grazing rates (ACT Government�2021).

#Text=Common native grasses include�Themeda,�Austrostipa,�Rytidosperma,�Poa, and�Bothriochloa�species, and common exotic grasses include�Avena,�Phalaris,�Bromus,�Aira, and�Vulpia�species (Smith et al�2023).
#Text=The largest grassland area (359ha) is in the southeast of the ACT at Jerrabomberra Grassland Nature Reserve (Environment ACT�2017).
#Text=We used a before_and_after control_impact experiment to document changes in invertebrate biodiversity following the addition of rocks to grasslands.
#Text=Two replicate sites were established in each of the five nature reserves (10 replicates in total).

#Text=Site locations were selected using random points generated in ArcMap 10 (Environmental Systems Research Institute) within grassland areas identified as naturally treeless and adjacent to areas with surface and embedded rock.
#Text=Each replicate site comprised two 2020m2�plots: one treatment and one control, which were randomly assigned.
#Text=Plots were spaced a minimum of 30m from existing fence lines or infrastructure and 53__398m from existing rocky outcrops.
#Text=Within replicates, the control and treatment plots were separated by a minimum of 100m and replicates within reserves were a minimum of 200m apart (Fig�1B).
#Text=Prior to the addition of surface rock, all plots contained 0% rock cover.
#Text=Despite the absence of data on rockiness at the exact study locations, nearby high floristic value grasslands in our study region contain dense rock cover (McDougall et al�2016).
#Text=Within each plot, we established two trapping stations, each comprising two 20L pitfall traps placed at 5 and 10m along a 15_m drift fence (four pitfalls per plot) (Fig�1C).

#Text=In April 2016, approximately 12t of crushed dacite bedrock (sourced from local development sites) was added to each treatment plot at approximately four rocks per square meter (approximately 20% cover).
#Text=Rocks were dispersed uniformly through the plot using a long reach excavator, and care was taken to ensure minimal to no soil disturbance.
#Text=Invertebrates were sampled from pitfall traps twice: once before rock addition in February 2016 (late summer) and again after rock addition in February 2019.
#Text=More frequent surveys (eg annual) were initially planned but not undertaken due to resourcing constraints.

#Text=However, we considered 3 years sufficient to detect invertebrate response to grassland restoration, as grasslands are often slow to respond to environmental change (Carbutt et al�2017; Carbutt & Kirkman�2022).
#Text=During each trapping session, traps remained open for five nights.
#Text=Traps were checked every day and vertebrates were recorded and released for another study (Palmer et al�2022).
#Text=Invertebrates greater than 0.5mm were collected daily and preserved in methylated spirits.

#Text=Invertebrate Identification\rAll invertebrate samples were identified to order based on external morphology using a stereomicroscope and, where finer_level identification was not possible but taxonomic distinctiveness was evident, assigned to morphospecies (Oliver & Beattie�1993,�1996; Beattle & Oliver�1994).

#Text=Further classification of Coleoptera (beetles), Blattodea (cockroaches), and Araneae (spiders) went to family level (Zborowski & Storey�2008; Hangay & Zborowski�2010; Lawrence & Slipinski�2013; Framenau et al�2014; Rentz�2014; Whyte & Anderson�2017; Rentz & Su�2019).
#Text=Orthoptera (crickets and grasshoppers) were identified to sub_family and Formicidae (ants) were identified to genus to aid in functional analysis (see below) (AntWiki�2011).
#Text=All other taxa (eg Isopoda, Diptera, and Lepidoptera) were grouped for analysis, hereafter referred to as Other.
#Text=Due to time constraints, Hemiptera and Hymenoptera (other than Formicidae) were not identified or quantified.
#Text=Larvae were excluded from the dataset for holometabolous insects (eg Coleoptera and Lepidoptera) as these could not be reliably identified.
#Text=Similarly, juveniles were excluded from the data for hemimetabolous insects (eg Orthoptera).

#Text=Functional Group and Response Variable Classification\rThree invertebrate groups, which were widely distributed (ie few absences in the dataset), and abundant, were selected for categorization into functional groups: Araneae (5.7% of all specimens), Coleoptera (17.1%), and Formicidae (70.6%) (Table�1).
#Text=Our study focused on these three key groups given their sensitivity to environmental variation and value as indicators of disturbance (Table�1).

#Text=Each taxon was allocated to a size category based on body length, and assigned to a trophic level (ie herbivore, detritivore, omnivore, or predator) (Hangay & Zborowski�2010; Framenau et al�2014) (Table�1).
#Text=Trophic levels were allocated based on known natural history and physiological traits such as mandible size.

#Text=Seven size categories were used for Coleoptera and Formicidae, which adequately differentiated among taxa in our samples: 0__2.5, 2.5__5, 5__10, 10__15, 15__20, 20__30mm and greater than 30mm (Table�1).
#Text=While size was used to categorize beetles and ants, size was not used for spiders as it is highly variable within species due to age and sex.
#Text=Some ant genera have polymorphic workers, which may have influenced the classification of morphospecies.
#Text=While acknowledging this limitation, we think it will have minimal effects on our conclusions because we used a finer_scale taxonomic resolution for ants.

#Text=Furthermore, functional grouping resulted in all polymorphic morphospecies being similarly categorized for analysis, meaning polymorphic worker traits should have minimal effects on the overall conclusions.
#Text=Morphospecies with insufficient functional information were excluded from analysis, resulting in the exclusion of only four Formicidae morphospecies.
#Text=Table 1.

#Text=�Invertebrate functional group classification and sensitivity to environmental variation hypothesized to be linked to rock restoration in natural temperate grasslands of the Australian Capital Territory.
#Text=Functional groups were used to analyze Araneae, Coleoptera, and Formicidae (there were too few observations of Blattodea and Orthoptera for functional analysis).

#Text=Taxon\rFunctional group\rValues classified\rSensitivity to environmental variation\rReferences\rAraneae\rRetreat type\rWeb, sac, burrow, free (roaming spiders with no fixed retreat type)\rRocks provide attachment points for webs, crevices for sac building spiders and shelter for spiders without fixed retreat types.
#Text=This could increase abundance and diversity of spiders using those retreat types if rocks were added.

#Text=Carvalho et al (2020) and Braschi et al (2021)\rAraneae\rPrey capture style\rSnare/web, active or vagrant (mobile hunters with no fixed retreat, may hunt actively or use the abandoned webs/burrows of other spider)\rRocks provide attachment points for snares (drop lines, snares, or webs) and increase the surface area for active hunters.
#Text=This could increase abundance of spiders where rocks have been added.

#Text=Carvalho et al (2020), Feng et al (2021), and Ham�k and Kouli (2021)\rColeoptera\rFlight habits\rFlies or does not fly\rRocks provide refuges for invertebrates and increase the surface area for invertebrates to commute.
#Text=Flight as a dispersal method, allows rapid recolonisation of habitat following disturbance.
#Text=As such, flying beetles may increase in abundance following rock addition to grasslands.
#Text=Abundance of non_flying ground_dwelling beetles may also increase due to refuge availability.

#Text=Driscoll et al (2020), Torma et al (2019), and Rahman et al (2021)\rColeoptera\rLarval habitat\rAbove, on, or below the ground (soil dwelling)\rRocks reduce plant biomass, increase refuge availability and limit disturbance from foraging mammals.
#Text=Ground_dwelling beetle larvae or predatory beetle larvae could increase in abundance due to increased refuge availability.
#Text=Reduction in aboveground plant biomass, could reduce abundance of beetle larvae that develop on plant material above and belowground.

#Text=Feng et al (2021)\rColeoptera, Formicidae\rSize\rGreater than or less than 5mm\rThermal tolerance is linked to body size and rock addition increases habitat microclimate variability and therefore thermal tolerance variability among the invertebrate community.
#Text=With increasing body size, upper thermal tolerance increases in ants and decreases in ground beetles.
#Text=Rock addition could result in an increase in small ants and large beetles.

#Text=Coleoptera: Moretti et al (2017) and Nervo et al (2021)\rFormicidae: Arnan et al (2014), Hoffmann and Andersen (2003), Linksvayer and Janssen (2009), and Baudier and O'Donnell (2018)\rColeoptera, Formicidae\rTrophic level\rHerbivore, detritivore, omnivore, and carnivore\rRocks reduce space for plant biomass and increase surface area for foraging and shelter.
#Text=Herbivore abundance may decrease with rock addition given a decrease in plant biomass.
#Text=Alternatively, predatory invertebrates and detritivores may increase in abundance due to increased surface area and refuges.

#Text=Coleoptera: Driscoll et al (2020), Feng et al (2021), and Torma et al (2019)\rFormicidae: Arnan et al (2014) and Moretti et al (2017)\rFormicidae\rNest site\rSoil (belowground), trees (arboreal), and mixed\rRocks increase surface area and provide shelter for invertebrate communities.
#Text=Ants use several substrates for nesting including under rocks and bark.
#Text=Ants that nest in soil could increase in abundance after rocks addition.

#Text=Hoffmann and Andersen (2003) and Linksvayer and Janssen (2009)\rFormicidae\rColony size\rMore or less than 100\rRock addition could affect resource availability through reduction in plant biomass and shelter sites.
#Text=Large colonies are generally more competitive due to increased foraging and defensive capacity, potentially resulting in an increase in abundance for ants with larger colony sizes.

#Text=Arnan et al (2014) and Linksvayer and Janssen (2009)\rFormicidae\rForaging style\rCooperative or solitary\rRocks increase surface area of microhabitat, plant biomass production and refuge availability.
#Text=Cooperative foraging allows for rapid discovery, defense, and collection of food resources.
#Text=Abundance of cooperative foragers could increase with greater environmental complexity (eg larger surface area).

#Text=Arnan et al (2014), Linksvayer and Janssen (2009), and Moretti et al (2017)\rAnalysis\rTo analyze the influence of rock treatment on the probability of occurrence, richness, diversity, and composition of invertebrate functional groups, we used linear and generalized linear mixed effects models (LMM and GLMM) in R (R Core Team�2023).
#Text=Each analysis used a different model family appropriate for the response variable, but we used the same model structure and approach for all variables.
#Text=Our primary hypothesis was that there would be an interaction between year and rock treatment, reflecting the before_after_control_impact study design.
#Text=That is, effect of rock treatment should not be detectable in 2016 before rocks were added; any effects should only become apparent in 2019 (Fig�1D).

#Text=Thus, we fitted three fixed effects in the model: year as a numeric variable (0 or 3), rock treatment as a two_level factorial variable (Control or Rock) and the interaction between these two variables.
#Text=We fitted replicate site nested within reserve as a random effect in all models to account for spatial clustering of samples.
#Text=We used a�p�value to determine the importance of the interaction term.

#Text=To determine whether treatment levels within years, within reserves were significantly different (eg control vs. rock in 2019), we calculated least_squares mean contrasts and 95% CI on the link scale using custom scripts (Roberts & Smith�2024).
#Text=We inferred important differences between levels within terms (eg control vs. rock in 2019) when the CI did not include zero.

#Text=We present results from all models and highlight results graphically where (1) the interaction term between year and treatment was significant (p<0.05) and (2) the interaction resulted from a significant difference between treatment levels in 2019, with no corresponding difference in 2016.
#Text=Our analysis goal was to examine the variation in species richness, diversity, and abundance of our functional groups for each target taxon.

#Text=When data are limited, however, such as with rare or spatially patchy taxa, important effects can be missed with models for abundance or continuous numeric data, as they are typically data hungry.
#Text=Thus, we began by modeling the probability of occurrence (presence/absence) for three taxa�Blattodea, Orthoptera, and Other�that fitted this description.

#Text=These groups had a high proportion of zeros (absences) (>15%) across the 160 observations in the data and low diversity at sites where they were present (mean number of species <2, maximum number of species <6).
#Text=For these groups, we modeled the probability of occurrence using binomial GLMMs with a logit link in the�lme4package (Bates et al�2014).
#Text=This allowed us to determine if rock addition affected the probability of occurrence for any taxon within these groups.
#Text=We then modeled species richness and diversity for the remaining taxa with adequate data (Araneae, Formicidae, and Coleoptera).
#Text=For richness, we used a negative binomial GLMM with a log link function using�glmmADMB�(Fournier et al�2012).
#Text=We calculated the Inverse Simpson's diversity index, hereafter diversity, as a measure of species diversity that incorporates evenness.
#Text=Zeroes in the data were transformed to very low values (0.000001) to allow model fitting.
#Text=Diversity was modeled using a GLMM with a log link function and a gamma error distribution using�lme4, appropriate for data with positive, continuous numeric data with heterogeneity.
#Text=To determine if invertebrate community composition changed with the addition of rocks, we performed a principal components analysis for each taxon separately using�prcomp�in R.
#Text=The first principal component accounted for the majority of variation in composition for all taxa (52__89%) and was selected for modeling community composition with a LMM in�lme4.

#Text=As the response of species richness to environmental modification can be scale_dependent, we analyzed�_diversity to assess whether spatial turnover in species composition varied at the reserve level.
#Text=These analyses were restricted to groups with sufficient data: Araneae, Coleoptera, and Formicidae.

#Text=We used Whittaker's (1960)�_diversity�=/, where��was the total number of species within a reserve (including both treatments so that the values would reflect species losses and gains under different rock treatments) and��was total species richness at the pitfall trap scale (the observation level�n=160).
#Text=Zero counts in the data returned infinite�_diversity values and were transformed to 0.1 for modeling.
#Text=To model�diversity, we used a GLMM with a log link function and gamma error distribution using�lme4.

#Text=To determine if the addition of rocks influenced the important functional components of the invertebrate community, we analyzed the occurrence and abundance of functional groups in Araneae, Coleoptera, and Formicidae (Table�1).
#Text=Groups identified as having sparse data (>20% zeros across the 160 observations) were modeled for occurrence only using a binomial GLMM with a logit link in�lme4.

#Text=Functional groups with an abundance greater than the number of plots sampled per year (>80) (Didham et al�1998) were modeled for abundance using a negative binomial GLMM with a log link function using�glmmADMB.
#Text=Results.

#Text=We recorded 29,164 individual invertebrates (the majority of which were ants, 70.55%) across 244 morphospecies (77 Araneae, 8 Blattodea, 61 Coleoptera, 51 Formicidae, 14 Orthoptera, and 33 Other).

#Text=Results from significant models are presented in the main document; raw abundance changes are shown in Figure�S1, and raw data and results from all models are within the analysis repository (Roberts & Smith�2024).
#Text=The probability of occurrence for Blattodea, Orthoptera, and Other taxa was not influenced by the interaction between rock addition and year (p>0.05) (Fig�S2).
#Text=There were no interactive effects of rock addition and year on species richness (Fig�S3a__c) or diversity (Fig�S3d__f) of Araneae, Coleoptera, and Formicidae.
#Text=There was no significant interaction between year and rock addition on community composition for any taxon (p>0.05) (Fig�S4).
#Text=There were significant main effects of year on community composition in Blattodea (p<0.001), Coleoptera (p<0.001), Orthoptera (p<0.001), and Other (p=0.025).
#Text=For these groups, community composition changed over the duration of the 3_year study in a way that was unrelated to rock addition (Fig�S4).
#Text=The interaction between rock addition and year did not significantly affect�_diversity for Araneae, Coleoptera, or Formicidae (p>0.05) (Fig�S5).
#Text=There was an interaction between rock addition and year on the abundance of snare_building spiders (p=0.021) (Fig�2).
#Text=This response was contrary to expectations, with a greater abundance of snare_building spiders in control plots in 2019 (Fig�2).
#Text=Similarly, big ants responded to the interaction between rock addition and year (p=0.001), with greater abundance in control plots in 2019 (Fig�3).
#Text=Four finer_scale groupings of big ants (omnivorous, cooperative foragers, mixed nesting sites, and large colony size) showed the same response (Fig�S6).
#Text=These groups likely drove the overall interaction (Fig�3) as not all finer_scale groupings of big ants showed the same response (data not shown).

#Text=Figure 2\rThe interactive effect of rock addition and year on the abundance (number of individuals) of snare_building spiders (model estimates and 95% CI) in the native temperate grasslands of southeastern Australia.
#Text=Abundances have been back_transformed from the link scale to reflect abundance on the response scale.
#Text=Shared letters indicate no significant difference.

#Text=Figure 3\rThe interactive effect of rock addition and year on the abundance (number of individuals) of big ants (model estimates and 95% CI) in the native temperate grasslands of southeastern Australia.
#Text=Abundances have been back_transformed from the link scale to reflect abundance on the response scale.
#Text=Shared letters indicate no significant difference.
#Text=Discussion.

#Text=We anticipated that the addition of rocks to native temperate grasslands would positively affect invertebrate biodiversity, but found no evidence to support either a positive or negative effect.
#Text=The only effects observed were positive increases in control plots in 2019, not decreases on rock plots.

#Text=Our study was conducted during a record_breaking drought for the study region (Australian Government Bureau of Meteorology), which likely impacted our ability to detect strong ecological responses.
#Text=In the following discussion, we assume that year effects were driven by this extreme climatic event.
#Text=However, other temporal factors over this time frame may have contributed to detecting changes, such as drift in community composition (Granville et al�2024).
#Text=The effects of the year on ant diversity and community composition of Blattodea, Coleoptera, Orthoptera, and other species were reflective of this.
#Text=Across this period of drought_induced environmental stress (2017__2019), snare_building spider abundance in control plots was greater than in plots with rocks added.
#Text=Big ants were significantly more abundant in plots that did not have rocks added during the period of environmental stress.
#Text=This overall response in big ants was driven by paired functional traits, including omnivory, cooperative foraging, having mixed nesting sites and large colony sizes.
#Text=Snare_building spiders and big ants were more abundant in plots without rocks in 2019.
#Text=For snare_building spiders, there was no year_effect, thus some aspect of the rock addition contributed to the difference in abundance in 2019.

#Text=Snare_building spiders are sensitive to disturbance (Laigle et al�2021; Oyarzabal & Guimar�es�2021) and use vegetation as attachment points (Braschi et al�2021; Ham�k & Kouli�2021; Oyarzabal & Guimar�es�2021).
#Text=The addition of rocks could have reduced these available attachment points for webs and broken_up the open space between existing vegetation (Braschi et al.�2021; Laigle et al.�2021).
#Text=We introduced rocks to grasslands to create a more structurally diverse habitat and in doing so, we provided a permanent elevated substrate.
#Text=Invertebrates residing on elevated substrates such as dense vegetation (ie snare_building spiders) could therefore become separated from the sampling space at ground level (pitfall traps).
#Text=For example, after rock addition, snare_building spiders could be blocked from entering traps by the rocks.

#Text=Snare_building spider abundance may not have been lower in treatment plots, but rather, due to the redistribution within the habitat, they were not captured in the traps as frequently, resulting in a lower relative functional abundance.

#Text=Similarly, the nonsignificant results observed for overall biodiversity metrics could have reflected the rocks influencing the detectability of shelter_seeking or sedentary invertebrate species (Hudgins et al�2012; Driscoll et al�2020).

#Text=Rocks provide shelter and nesting sites for several invertebrate taxa such as ants, millipedes, and spiders (Goldsbrough et al�2003; Croak et al�2012; Lawrence et al�2012), which could result in reduced detection of morphospecies from these groups.

#Text=However, general knowledge about how rock addition affects invertebrate biodiversity is still quite limited, and we are unaware of any studies that have examined the influence of rocks on invertebrate detectability.
#Text=This points to a necessary topic for future abiotic restoration work.
#Text=For most research on ants, ecosystem function is usually closely associated with phylogeny (Hoffmann & Andersen�2003; Linksvayer & Janssen�2009).

#Text=For example, taxa are commonly grouped into functional categories such as competition specialists (eg Dolichoderinae and Myrmicinae) or stress specialists (eg Generalized Myrmicinae) (Hoffmann & Andersen�2003; Linksvayer & Janssen�2009).
#Text=In our study, between 2016 and 2019, Dolichoderinae sp. 2 (identified as�Anonychomyrma�sp) contributed most to the increased abundance (24 increased to 138).
#Text=There were 120 individuals of this morphospecies in one control plot (Jerrabomberra East) in 2019, accounting for 87% of all specimens collected in 2019.
#Text=This was the only big ant (>5mm) to display this level of increase.
#Text=As such, body size may not be a functional response to stress or disturbance in this experiment, but rather a feature of the individual species responding to the change.

#Text=The higher abundance that we observed for big ants, was linked to several other functional traits, including omnivory, cooperative foraging, having a mixed nesting site preference and large colony size.
#Text=In this system, therefore, ant body size might not provide a competitive advantage, but rather reflects a combination of generalist traits, including being big.

#Text=In other studies on ants, body size has been positively linked to increasing latitude and temperature extremes, but these studies often note functional correlations with phylogeny (Linksvayer & Janssen�2009; Arnan et al�2014).
#Text=Native temperate grasslands are heavily fragmented in Australia and globally and, within the study area, are separated by urban and agricultural land.
#Text=This fragmentation might have been associated with the limited response observed in invertebrate biodiversity to rock addition.
#Text=Habitat fragmented from the expansion of urbanization, industrial agriculture and mining has been associated with declines in invertebrate biodiversity (Oliver et al�2016).

#Text=The overall biodiversity and corresponding species pool of a region are linked to the distribution and diversity (eg heterogeneity) of habitats within that region (Fournier et al�2012; Fahrig�2020).

#Text=Habitat fragments often display distinct functional diversity compared to neighboring habitats, where this difference is linked to the size and environmental heterogeneity of the area hosting the regional species pool (Fournier et al�2012; Barton et al�2013).
#Text=With increasing habitat fragmentation, remnant invertebrate populations are increasingly samples of the original total biodiversity (Fahrig�2020).

#Text=Additionally, the movement of individuals from fragmented populations is limited, which limits their capacity to recover from neighboring populations following local extinction from stochastic environmental events (Scholtz & Twidwell�2022).

#Text=Thus, the limited response of invertebrate biodiversity to rock addition might be associated with the multiple interactions driven by the sensitivity of the grasslands to stress (drought) and disturbance (such as rock addition) (Gang et al�2014), the extended recovery time observed for native grassland fragments (Carbutt et al�2017; Carbutt & Kirkman�2022) and the limited capacity for invertebrate recruitment to local populations (Belyea & Lancaster�1999; Toft et al�2019; Feng et al�2021).
#Text=Based on our observations, the addition of rocks to grasslands did not benefit overall invertebrate biodiversity, but there may be other benefits of rocks restoration.

#Text=For example, vertebrates, especially lizards, have benefited from rock addition through the provision of surfaces for thermal regulation (Croak et al�2012; McDougall et al�2016; Palmer et al�2022).
#Text=This could explain the general lack of invertebrate response to rocks in this study if lizards were posing top_down effects through predation.
#Text=However, Palmer et al (2022) did not observe an increase in lizard abundance at the same sites used in our study, despite observations that lizards were using the rocks.

#Text=We documented short_term effects during a record_breaking drought; thus, continued monitoring is required to determine if grassland invertebrates respond more strongly in the long term (eg 10years).

#Text=Increasing the size of grassland fragments (Scholtz & Twidwell�2022) and providing corridors to facilitate the dispersal of regional populations between native fragments could result in a more rapid and observable change to invertebrate biodiversity in response to rock addition.

#Text=Importantly, rock addition in native temperate grasslands did not negatively impact invertebrate biodiversity and might be beneficial to the long_term conservation and restoration of vertebrate and invertebrate communities.
